Key Arguments: The Human Rights Law Centre supports regulation not based on industry self-regulation or co-regulation, citing its failure to address disinformation and hate speech.
They advocate for a regulatory regime similar to the EU's Digital Services Act, emphasizing transparency, risk assessment, and user control over data.
The submission highlights the need for digital platforms to be accountable for human rights impacts, suggesting that platforms should undertake risk assessments and implement mitigation measures.
They argue that digital platforms' algorithms can manipulate public opinion and infringe on human rights, necessitating regulation to ensure transparency and accountability.
The submission calls for a data access regime to support civil society and expert research into disinformation and hate speech.
Notable Quotes: Suggestions by some that digital platforms should not be regulated at all because of concerns regarding the right to freedom of speech, fundamentally misunderstands the nature of the right, and ignores all other rights.
Digital platforms are not benign, inert, or neutral repositories of data and content.
The Australian Government should not leave it to digital platforms to determine how they will guarantee that all Australians will have their human rights protected and affirmed online.
